title: Scroll Panels
narrative:
This specification is dedicated to showing how to use the
    `JScrollPanels` class, a custom SwingTree component that
    is designed to display a list of scrollable panels
    which can be populated with any kind of interactive UI
    based on any kind of sub-view model type.

features.id: The `JScrollPanels` instance can visually represent a view model consisting of sub-view models.

extraInfo:
Note that we use a pre-made example view model here.
            Feel free to look at the source code of the view model
            to see what it is doing.
            All you need to know is that it is a view model
            that contains a `Vars` based property list of sub-view models.

blocks.text: We instantiate the view model.
We create a view for our view model...
code: throw new IllegalStateException("Index mismatch: " + i + " != " + evm.position().get());

blocks.text: We build the root component:
It was successfully created.
The view contains as many sub-views as the view model has entries.
We remove an item from the entry list.
The view is updated accordingly.

features.id: Use a simple property list of Strings to populate a scroll panel.

extraInfo:
Instead of using a view model, we use simple String instances
            to create views from each of the items in the list
            and populate a scroll panel with them.

blocks.text: A simple property list of Strings.
We create a view for our list...
We build the root component:
The view was successfully created.
The view contains as many sub-views as the list has items.
We remove an item from the list.
The view is updated.
We add an item to the list.
The view is updated.

features.id: A property list is bound to a scroll panel compute efficiently. [0]

extraInfo:
You can bind a string based tuple property and a view supplier 
            to dynamically add or remove tabs. The GUI will only update the
            tabs that have changed.

blocks.text: A string tuple property, a view supplier and a panel UI node.
We unpack the pane and the expected differences:
We run the operation on the tuple...
We unpack the updated components:
The tabbed pane is updated.
The components at `-1` are totally new.
We test the following operations:

blocks.text: A string tuple property, a view supplier and a panel UI node.
We unpack the pane and the expected differences:
We run the operation on the tuple...
We unpack the updated components:
The tabbed pane is updated.
The components at `-1` are totally new.
We unpack the panel contents:
The view texts a equal to the string representations of the tuple elements.
We test the following operations:

operation: { Tuple.of("Comp a", "Comp b", "Comp c", "Comp d", "Comp e") }
{ it.clear().addAll("Comp a", "Comp b", "Comp c", "Comp d", "Comp e") }

features.id: A tuple property can be bound to a scroll panel bi-directionally and compute efficiently. [0]

extraInfo:
You can bind a string based tuple property and a view supplier 
            to dynamically add or remove tabs. The GUI will only update the

blocks.text: A string tuple property, a view supplier and a panel UI node.
code: var tuple = Tuple.of("Comp 1", "Comp 2", "Comp 3", "Comp 4", "Comp 5").mapTo(StringAsId, it -> new StringAsId(it))

blocks.text: We unpack the pane and the expected differences:
The components have the correct initial text displayed on them:
We run the operation on the tuple...
We unpack the updated components:
The tabbed pane is updated.
The components at `-1` are totally new.
We unpack the panel contents:
The view texts a equal to the string representations of the tuple elements.
We test the following operations:

operation: { it.addAll(new StringAsId("Comp X"), new StringAsId("Comp Y")) }
{ it.clear().addAll(new StringAsId("Comp 1"), new StringAsId("Comp 2"), new StringAsId("Comp 3"), new StringAsId("Comp 4"), new StringAsId("Comp 5")) }
{ Tuple.of("Comp a", "Comp b", "Comp c", "Comp d", "Comp e").mapTo(StringAsId, s -> new StringAsId(s)) }
{ it.clear().addAll(new StringAsId("Comp a"), new StringAsId("Comp b"), new StringAsId("Comp c"), new StringAsId("Comp d"), new StringAsId("Comp e")) }

features.id: A tuple property can be bound to a scroll panel bi-directionally and compute efficiently. [1]

features.id: A scroll panels widget maintains the correct state after a series of operations applied to a bound property list.

blocks.text: We create some constants for the test.
A property list of strings and a scroll panels widget.
code: var list = Vars.of(ABURAAGE, TEMPEH, TOFU, SEITAN, MISO)

blocks.text: We unpack the content panel and the initial components:
The initial components are correctly displayed.
We remove the third item from the list.
The third component is removed from the view.
The labels are re-used.
We now re-add the third item to the list to be at an earlier position.
The third component is re-added to the view.
The labels are re-used, except for the new one.
We now replace a single item with itself.
Nothing changes in the view.
The labels are re-used except for the tofu label, which remains a new one.
We now replace all the items with themselves.
code: list.setAllAt(0, ABURAAGE, TOFU, TEMPEH, SEITAN, MISO)

blocks.text: Nothing changes in the view.
The labels are re-used except for the tofu label, which remains a new one.
We now add a completely new item to the list.
The new item is added to the view.
code: updatedComps.collect({it.text}) == [ABURAAGE, TOFU, TEMPEH, SEITAN, MISO, natto].collect({it.text().get()})

blocks.text: The labels are re-used except for the new one.
We now reverse the order of the list.
The list is reversed in the view.
code: updatedComps.collect({it.text}) == [natto, MISO, SEITAN, TEMPEH, TOFU, ABURAAGE].collect({it.text().get()})
